title: Russian Annexation of Crimea (2014)
summary: Russia seized Crimea from Ukraine in February-March 2014, following Euromaidan. Russian forces without insignia ('little green men') took control of the peninsula. Russia held a disputed referendum and formally annexed Crimea on March 18, 2014. Not recognized by international community.

russian_perspective.official_narrative: Crimea voluntarily reunified with Russia after a legitimate referendum. Russia was protecting ethnic Russians and Russian speakers from the 'fascist' Kyiv government. Crimea was historically Russian (until 1954) and has a Russian majority. This was correcting a historical injustice.

justifications: Protecting Russian speakers from Ukrainian nationalists
Crimea was Russian until Khrushchev 'gifted' it to Ukraine in 1954
Crimea has Russian majority and cultural ties to Russia
Preventing NATO from taking Sevastopol naval base
Correcting the historical injustice of Soviet-era borders
media_framing.visual_framing: Celebrations, Putin's speech, referendum voting, Russian flag raising
media_framing.prohibited_narratives: Cannot call it 'annexation' or 'occupation' in Russian media

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: In people's hearts and minds, Crimea has always been an inseparable part of Russia. This firm conviction is based on truth and justice and was passed from generation to generation.

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: What about the Kosovo precedent? Our western colleagues created it with their own hands. In a very similar situation, they recognized Kosovo's secession from Serbia legitimate.

key_quotes.speaker: Putin
key_quotes.quote: I gave the order to the Defense Ministry - it was in the early morning - to raise the flag of Russia over Crimea.

russian_perspective.evolution: Initially denied Russian military involvement (March 2014). Later admitted operation (March 2015 documentary). By 2022, Crimea annexation framed as precedent justifying broader Ukraine operation.

western_perspective.official_narrative: Russia illegally annexed Crimea in violation of international law, Ukrainian sovereignty, and the Budapest Memorandum (1994) which guaranteed Ukraine's territorial integrity in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons. The referendum was illegitimate, held under military occupation.

violations_cited: Use of military force without insignia (war crime)

counter_arguments: Referendum held at gunpoint cannot be legitimate
Crimean Tatars (12% of population) boycotted referendum
Russia's 1954 transfer argument ignores Ukrainian independence
Annexation sets dangerous precedent for might-makes-right

verified_claims: Russian forces without insignia seized Crimean Parliament on Feb 27, 2014
Unidentified armed men ('little green men') took control of airports, infrastructure
Putin later admitted these were Russian military forces
Referendum held March 16, 2014: official result 96.77% to join Russia
Russia formally annexed Crimea on March 18, 2014
UN General Assembly Resolution 68/262 (March 27, 2014) declared referendum invalid (100 yes, 11 no, 58 abstain)
Western sanctions imposed on Russia starting March 2014
Crimea was part of Russian Empire until 1954, when transferred to Ukrainian SSR
disputed_claims: Referendum legitimacy (Russia: legitimate; West/Ukraine: held at gunpoint)
Whether ethnic Russians were actually threatened by Kyiv

data_points.budapest_memorandum: Signed 1994 by Russia, US, UK guaranteeing Ukraine's borders

propaganda_techniques_observed: Fait accompli (quick military action, then referendum)
Victim inversion (Russia protecting victims, not being aggressor)
